WRT 120 - Effective Writing 1

This calendar lists all of the readings, assignments, and activities for the class. Remember that material needs to be read, and assignments completed prior to the class meeting they are listed for. For your convenience, I list the information for the upcoming class meeting at the top of the page, but consult the full schedule below to get a sense of whatâ€™s coming up in the weeks ahead.

This semester's Calendar is still being finalized! Last semester's calendar is displayed below!

Monday August 29

  • Read:
  • Class Activity: Intro and syllabus
  • Assignment Due:

    • Wednesday August 31

  • Read:
    • Ten Ways To Think About Writing: Metaphoric Musings for College Writing Student
  • Class Activity: Review of "theory of writing" prewrite - Compare their thoughts from BEFORE the writing spaces reading to the writing spaces reading. What was similar? What was unexpected?
  • Assignment Due:

    • Friday September 2

  • Read:
  • Class Activity:
  • Assignment Due:

    • Monday September 5

  • Read:
  • Class Activity: LABOR DAY
  • Assignment Due:

    • Wednesday September 7

  • Read:
    • Effective tweets, memes, fb posts (collected by instructor)
  • Class Activity: Discuss how selected tweets, memes, etc achieve their goals, consider genre, context audience. Also consider ideology, genre features.
  • Assignment Due:

    • Friday September 9

  • Read:
    • 'Navigating Genres' (Writing Spaces)
  • Class Activity: A look at genre through the lens of Youtube's genre bending movie trailers. Discussion of upcoming snark and elegy assignment. Extra-credit assignment: create a genre-bending remix.
  • Assignment Due:

    • Monday September 12

  • Read:
    • 'Joyless Children's Games in Western Art History' (Mallory Ortberg, The Toast)
    • 'I know what clean smells like' (Mallory Ortberg, The Toast)
    • 'Everything that's Wrong of Raccoons,' (Mallory Ortberg, The Toast)
    • OPTIONAL: 'A Generic College Paper' (John Wu, McSweeney's)
  • Class Activity: Review snark essay and discuss the genre of 'snark.' What makes it effective? What invites the reader to share the author's disdain? Extra-credit assignment describe another genre of blog post, convince me to allow you to use it for the genre assignment. Extra-credit assignment: find a CC licensed image of a famous artwork and make a snarky comment about it.
  • Assignment Due: Revised theory of writing

    • Wednesday September 14

  • Read:
    • 'My Aaron Swartz, Whom I loved' (Quinn Norton, Medium)
    • 'Playing Shiva' (Eric Meyer)
    • Bonus: 'The Last Post' (Derek Miller)
  • Class Activity: Review elegy. What makes it effective? How does it evoke the author's mourning and invite us to share?
  • Assignment Due:

    • Friday September 16

  • Read:
  • Class Activity: Writing project 1 prewriting: brainstorm 3 things you might mourn and 3 things you might mock. Compare with a partner. Which is the ripest target for an essay?
  • Assignment Due:

    • Monday September 19

  • Read:
    • 'The Blue Shell and It's Discontents' (Ian Bogost)
  • Class Activity: Discuss Bogost's piece. How does it use genre features we saw in the previous snark pieces? How does it build on these features and use them to accomplish its own goals?
  • Assignment Due:

    • Wednesday September 21

  • Read:
  • Class Activity: Explicit discussion of images and design in our readings to date
  • Assignment Due:

    • Friday September 23

  • Read:
    • 'The Painted Desert' (Quinn Norton, Medium)
    • 'Nobody's Detroit' (Philip Levine, Harper's)
  • Class Activity: Discussion focusing on all the snarks and elegies. Which was the most successful of the lot at moving you and why?
  • Assignment Due:

    • Monday September 26

  • Read:
  • Class Activity: Discussion of mess drafts, what was the process of writing them like? What did we learn along the way?
  • Assignment Due: Initial "mess" draft of snark or elegy

    • Wednesday September 28

  • Read:
    • Snark or elegy of the student's choosing
    • 'From Topic to Presentation' (Writing Spaces)
  • Class Activity: Discussion of model essay chosen by students. Why did they choose them, why did they find them useful examples or models?
  • Assignment Due:

    • Friday September 30

  • Read:
  • Class Activity: Completed snark or elegy, revision. Peer review.
